Speaking of libvirt's defaults, I think it is worth adding some form of the below note:

Prior to libvirt v4.7.0 libvirt picked its default machine type for x86, 'pc', as reported by QEMU's default.  From libvirt v4.7.0 onwards, libvirt _explicitly_ declared the "preferred" default for x86 as 'pc' (and appropriate values for other architectures), and only uses QEMU's reported default (whatever that may be) if 'pc' does not exist.  This was done "to isolate applications from hypervisor changes that may cause incompatibilities" -- i.e. if, or when, QEMU changes its default machine type to something else.  (Refer to this libvirt commit: https://libvirt.org/git/?p=libvirt.git;a=commit;h=26cfb1a3 -- "qemu: ensure default machine types don't change if QEMU changes")

so i was testing this on one of my vm where i have nested virt and that exposed another error.

that is if i set virt-type=kvm this raiase and exception for architture that are not my native architure as i cannot run them with kvm accleartion.

so i think we have 5 options to resolve this.

1.) do not pass the virt type ever which will alway resutl in calling libvirt with virt-type=None
2.) convert virt_type=kvm to virt_type=qemu if the arch is not the same as the native one but otherwise set the virt_type to whatever is in the config.
3.) if the virt-type is not qemu always pass None
4.) catch the exception that is raised and skip this arch as its incompatible with the virt-type.
5.) catch the exception and check again without the virt type set.

im leaning towrds number 2,3 or 5.

what do people think.

if you have virt-type=qemu the current patch seams to be sufficnt by the way so we just need to cover virt-type=kvm
although we should quickly test lxc as weel.

personally i think we proably dont need to call this funtion if we are not useing virt-type qemu or kvm but that is a seperate mater.

So I've read the IRC transcript.

tl;dr — yes, option-4 seems most reasonable (and indeed, logging at DEBUG level).

A couple of things based on my remarks on IRC:

* The output of domCapabilities() with or without 'virt_type' should be the same — i.e. if libvirt "knows" that KVM is available on the host, then it will default to 'kvm', whether you pass the 'virt_type' parameter or not.  You can compare and `diff` (which is none) here[1] from the outputs here [2][3].

* That said, if Nova _knows_ the 'virt_type', then it should explicitly specify it.

* The option-2 above, as I noted on IRC is too black magic, and can be an unwanted surprise for the operator.  Let's avoid it.

* And as Adam guessed on IRC, the difference in output of getDomainCapabilities() will be non-trivial for virt_type as KVM vs. QEMU.  Compare the `diff` here[4].

[1] https://kashyapc.fedorapeople.org/getDomainCapabilities/diff_domCapabilities_of_virt_type_kvm_and_none.txt
[2] https://kashyapc.fedorapeople.org/getDomainCapabilities/domCapabilities_without_virt_type.txt
[3] https://kashyapc.fedorapeople.org/getDomainCapabilities/domCapabilities_with_virt_type_kvm.txt
[4] https://kashyapc.fedorapeople.org/getDomainCapabilities/diff_domCapabilities_of_virt_type_kvm_and_qemu.txt

http://eavesdrop.openstack.org/irclogs/%23openstack-nova/%23openstack-nova.2019-07-24.log.html#t2019-07-24T16:33:41

we decided to go with option 4 unless anyone else disagrees and catch the excpeiton and skip that architecture if its not compatible with the virt-type you have set in the config.

we might want to log the fact we are skipping at debug level but this is not an error since ubunut and possibly other distos install all qemu emulator by default so we dont want to log a at a higher log level to avoid spamming the logs.

cinder/templates/job-storage-init.yaml.message: We were also discussing implementation of multi backends internally. If there are multiple ceph clusters, there should be a separate ceph.conf. This patch seems to use one ceph.conf. Does this patch support multiple ceph clusters? If so, how can  support it?

This patch does not support multiple ceph clusters. It just extends existing chart to support multiple ceph backends on the same cluster. It allows you to partition existing Ceph storage space into let's say faster pools backed by SSDs and slower pools backed by HDDs then define separate backends in Cinder for each of them.

Zuul is failing because of these references. 

  value: {{ (index $envAll.Values.conf.ceph.pools $backend.rbd_pool).app_name | quote }}
  value: {{ (index $envAll.Values.conf.ceph.pools $backend.rbd_pool).crush_rule |   quote }}
  value: {{ (index $envAll.Values.conf.ceph.pools $backend.rbd_pool).replication | quote }}
  value: {{ (index $envAll.Values.conf.ceph.pools $backend.rbd_pool).chunk_size | quote }}

You need to change values.yaml to:

  ceph:
    pools:
      backup:
        replication: 3
        crush_rule: replicated_rule
        chunk_size: 8
        app_name: cinder-backup
      rbd1:
        replication: 1
        crush_rule: replicated_rule
        chunk_size: 8
        app_name: cinder-volume

If you are going to use the pool name to allow individual pool creation with unique values then for consistency you should also change 'backup' to 'cinder.backups' and update job-backup-storage-init.yaml.

deliverables/train/cloudkitty.yaml.message:
Do you know of a downstream consumer that needs to pick this up? The switch from cycle-with-milestones to cycle-with-rc was in part to stop making releases that were not actually needed, then only doing an RC to prepare for the final release.

We can still do beta releases, but I just want to make sure you are aware that they are not needed, and we really want to encourage only doing them when there is someone that wants to use them.

There are several people who need this and will upgrade their deployment once the release has been made. 

It was suggested here https://review.opendev.org/#/c/635657/ to make beta releases if we need to release some features.

Ideally, we'd like to switch back to "cycle-with-intermediary", as this release  should be 9.1.0, but given that we are a small team, we'll probably not be able to make more than two releases per cycle (including the final one).

I think this should be AVX512_VNNI to match up with how it's spelled in the reference.

(Note that this is not inconsistent with the ones before it, which are spelled without the underscore in the reference.)

That's okay; not all of the CPU feature strings map exactly to their corresponding trait names. Where this is used by the libvirt driver there is a dict [1] rather than e.g. an algorithm to construct the trait name from the feature name.

Looking at that dict, it's actually not at all clear where the existing names came from. IMO the underscore makes it more readable, so that's a win.

But given what you've shown, I guess it's not worth blocking on.

[1] https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/src/commit/d358df32f7a2a1125962e27f2425359c768f79c1/nova/virt/libvirt/utils.py#L49-L82

I *agree with you* after I checked the Intel instruction set (https://software.intel.com/sites/default/files/managed/c5/15/architecture-instruction-set-extensions-programming-reference.pdf) and examined the naming of Linux kernel.

Kernel:
 
"""
david@david-unc:~/work/linux/arch$ grep -ri "vnni"
x86/include/asm/cpufeatures.h:#define X86_FEATURE_AVX512_VNNI           (16*32+11) /* Vector Neural Network Instructions */
x86/include/asm/cpufeatures.h:#define X86_FEATURE_AVX512_4VNNIW (18*32+ 2) /* AVX-512 Neural Network Instructions */
x86/kvm/cpuid.c:                F(VAES) | F(VPCLMULQDQ) | F(AVX512_VNNI) | F(AVX512_BITALG) |
x86/kvm/cpuid.c:                F(AVX512_4VNNIW) | F(AVX512_4FMAPS) | F(SPEC_CTRL) |
x86/kernel/cpu/cpuid-deps.c:    { X86_FEATURE_AVX512_VNNI,      X86_FEATURE_AVX512VL  },
x86/kernel/cpu/cpuid-deps.c:    { X86_FEATURE_AVX512_4VNNIW,    X86_FEATURE_AVX512F   },
"""

*BUT* I still need to point out that QEMU and libvirt follow the name of "avx512vnni", which does not follow the naming of reference.

"""
david@david-unc:~/work/qemu$ grep -ri "vnni"
target/i386/t2:            CPUID_7_0_ECX_AVX512VNNI,
target/i386/hvf/x86_cpuid.c:            edx &= CPUID_7_0_EDX_AVX512_4VNNIW | CPUID_7_0_EDX_AVX512_4FMAPS;
target/i386/cpu.c:            "gfni", "vaes", "vpclmulqdq", "avx512vnni",
target/i386/cpu.c:            NULL, NULL, "avx512-4vnniw", "avx512-4fmaps",
target/i386/cpu.c:            CPUID_7_0_ECX_AVX512VNNI,
target/i386/cpu.c:            CPUID_7_0_ECX_AVX512VNNI | CPUID_7_0_ECX_AVX512BITALG |
target/i386/cpu.c:            CPUID_7_0_ECX_AVX512VNNI | CPUID_7_0_ECX_AVX512BITALG |
target/i386/cpu.c:            CPUID_7_0_EDX_AVX512_4VNNIW | CPUID_7_0_EDX_AVX512_4FMAPS,
target/i386/cpu.h:#define CPUID_7_0_ECX_AVX512VNNI (1U << 11)
target/i386/cpu.h:#define CPUID_7_0_EDX_AVX512_4VNNIW (1U << 2) /* AVX512 Neural Network Instructions */
Binary file .git/objects/pack/pack-431a9ba6adaca798b7dee8f5695133ba562cff0f.pack matches

trove_tempest_plugin/adapters/__init__.p.message:
Why couldn't be coded in a single line:  
   from tempest.config import CONF
, as in trove_tempest_plugin\managers\floating_ips.py, 
instead of a couple of lines:
  from tempest import config
  CONF = config.CONF
?
I was suggested by other contributors to follow this pattern. Seems to be a convention that they adopted in the project. Will change the import in floating_ips module.
Should we allow to call such a function None ?

In most cases we want to get adapter for datastore set in Tempest configuration. Fetching datastore from config and passing it to this method each time would be a unnecessary burden. That's why the argument was implemented as optional (datastore=None).

If someone passes "None" value as argument explicitely they will still experience the same behaviour. I don't see any problem with that.

Maybe a better way is to define a dict(datastore => adapter_class)?
We could also try to think about generating such dict dynamically based on available files in a convention over configuration fashion.
I like the ideas. Will try to refactor.

I would opt to fix/hardcode the major (or stable) adapters, and consider experimental/plugin section/routine as an option to upload further adapters (afaik, Trove has the experimental facility for datastores).

In terms of design patterns and adapter-as-a-plugin, "registry" pattern might be worth looking at. In nutshell: every class (every adapter) derived from AdapterBase, automatically becomes registered in a global variable. Illustration: https://github.com/faif/python-patterns/blob/master/behavioral/registry.py

After your suggestion I attempted to apply the registry pattern, however, ended up with a similar problem related to mapping configured datastore names to class names in the registry dict.

In test configuration we have:

 datastore = mariadb|cassandra|redis

And the registry provides the following dict:

 {
     'MariadbAdapter': MariadbAdapter,
     'CassandraAdapter': MariadbAdapter,
     'RedisAdapter': MariadbAdapter,
     ...
 }

In order to corelate config value with registry key, we would have to do string interpolation e.g.

 adapter_cls_name = "%sAdapter"

Another option was to add class-level attribute to adapter classes e.g. "adapter_name" and use them as registry keys.

Both approaches were not too elegant.

Since everything seemed to reduce to hardcoding a dict with mapping between datastores and adapter classes, I decided to use entry_points which allow to achieve exactly that and additionaly provide pluggable interface.

Many other OpenStack projects use common stevedore library for loading drivers from entry points [1-2].

Anyway, thanks for note about registry pattern. It is one of these interesting design patterns that I didn't know about before. Happy to learn something new :)

I'm also opened for further discussion in this topic.

[1] https://github.com/openstack/oslo.messaging/blob/master/setup.cfg#L39
[2] https://github.com/openstack/oslo.messaging/blob/815e25e55b73bacbe0dba61d153024d395864ded/oslo_messaging/transport.py#L204

trove_tempest_plugin/adapters/base.py.message: We should define here API for adapters here explicitly

I documented methods of the interface in individual docstrings of these methods. Isn't it sufficient?

What do you propose to describe in the docstring of the class?

For private properties it is recommended to use single underscore:
https://www.python.org/dev/peps/pep-0008/?#method-names-and-instance-variables

That was my intention. I don't want child classes to override __client variable since it is managed by property method defined in the base class.

This is how I marked the variable as private to the base. If I wanted to mark it as protected and allow overriding in child classes, I would use single underscore as you suggest.

Using double underscore herein is perhaps for "mangling" whose purpose differs and it prevents accidental variable override in a child class. Illustration:

class Parent:
    _not_mangled = 'non-M'
    __mangled = 'M'

class Child(Parent):
    def __init__(self):
        try:
            print(self.__mangled)
        except Exception as ex:
            print("Error: {}".format(ex))

        print(self._not_mangled)
        self._not_mangled = 'Changed'
        print(self._not_mangled)
        print(self._Parent__mangled)

c = C()

# Output:
# Error: 'Child' object has no attribute '_Child__mangled'
# non-M
# Changed
# M

IMHO we could compress it a little bit. In basically each method you are repeating similar message in short version and in the longer version.
Also ping() method name seems to be self-explanatory.
Cannot compress. Multi-line docstring must have summary line.

How do we know the FIP NAT entry has been updated at this time?  Seems like there will be a possible race if the agent isn't done.

You think we should add some loop like wait_until_true with a very small timeout?

The reason why I wanted to add this test was to catch race condition in networking-ovn where it didn't configure fip properly but later was recovered by running maintenance task. Seems like we have the race condition the other way around now in the test (FIP is not configured yet) :)

About the false positives: yes if they're not too frequent. If we have a failure ratio of 10% that may become unnoticed due to rechecks :) Remember that when we run this test alone, we get 100% of false positives :)

About the whitebox testing: no need for checking periodically. If you execute the API call and straight away you verify the NB contents, then it's all good from neutron-server perspective.
You can argue that the NB contents can be correct due to the maintenance task but even if it takes us 5s to verify, the chance for the maint task for having kicked in is less than 2% (5s/300s which is the current interval). IMO, this would be a good way to make sure that all is as it should be.
I agree, of course, that tempest is not the place for this and this is why I said tobiko or something else.

Another possibility that I'd like to explore is to run tempest in networking-ovn gate with the maintenance task disabled. We want the maintenance task to be present in production as a safeguard mechanism but perhaps in tempest, it will do nothing but hiding issues. This is not perhaps the right place to discuss it but I'm curious to hear from you guys about this.

@Jakub: so how often this maintenance task is running and can fix this problem in networking-ovn? IMO even with wait_until_true You can sometimes have the case when connectivity will be recovered by this maintenance task instead of "normal" configuration. But TBH, is it that bad if it's recovered after few seconds? Maybe simple usage of check_servers_hostnames() together with wait_until_true would be enough to ensure that FIP is switched to new port for sure.

I think that the only good way to verify the race condition in networking-ovn is through whitebox testing (tobiko or similar) and actually assert that the NAT entry is there right after updating the FIP minimizing the window for the maint task to kick in.

That said, I agree with Brian and this is racey. In loaded systems, even if neutron server writes to the NB database the new NAT entry, ovn-northd will have to populate the SB database and this has to be propagated and processed by ovn-controller in the chassis where the VM is bound to and install the right flows in the switch for the dataplane to converge.

My guess is that this test would not be green 100% if you run it on a multinode system with certain amount of load. At the very least, I'd do the wait_until_true for a small timeout as you suggest.
But then, we may get false positives because it can be the maint task the one making the dataplane to converge.

A side question that comes to my mind is: What if we make the maintenance task interval configurable in networking-ovn (I'm against too many config options but we may have a good argument here)

> About the false positives: yes if they're not too frequent. If we
 > have a failure ratio of 10% that may become unnoticed due to
 > rechecks :) Remember that when we run this test alone, we get 100%
 > of false positives :)

It was another test that had server creation after FIP was updated, that's why I wanted a new test that updates FIP and checks immediately.

 > 
 > About the whitebox testing: no need for checking periodically. If
 > you execute the API call and straight away you verify the NB
 > contents, then it's all good from neutron-server perspective.

There is still small time window between API call getting processed and writing into OVN database, so it can happen you check NB content before neutron-server writes into it, no?

 > You can argue that the NB contents can be correct due to the
 > maintenance task but even if it takes us 5s to verify, the chance
 > for the maint task for having kicked in is less than 2% (5s/300s
 > which is the current interval). IMO, this would be a good way to
 > make sure that all is as it should be.
 > I agree, of course, that tempest is not the place for this and this
 > is why I said tobiko or something else.

If you care about database content, we can have a test in functional tests that verifies update call to mech driver updates NB db with expected data. Functional test has no maintenance task running so there is only a single writer who could fix the stuff. However that would not cover the scenario of FIP updates that we're missing completely nowadays.

 > 
 > Another possibility that I'd like to explore is to run tempest in
 > networking-ovn gate with the maintenance task disabled. We want the
 > maintenance task to be present in production as a safeguard
 > mechanism but perhaps in tempest, it will do nothing but hiding
 > issues. This is not perhaps the right place to discuss it but I'm
 > curious to hear from you guys about this.
That's a good idea!

Hi,

Jumping on this :D

I think that the wait_until_true() would be good here, by the time we update the FIP and the check, it seems to be clear that it can race.

Regarding Daniel suggestion about disabling the maintenance when running tempest, this is an interesting idea. I like the idea because tempest is not really testing things under load, it's mostly checking correctness so if the maintenance fix something it can hide a potential problem (just like it happened with this patch).

There's two aspects of the maintenance work:

1. The maintenance task itself that runs every 5 minutes. This is to ensure that we get eventual consistency between both databases and it can be disabled easily.

2. The CheckRevisionNumbers OVSDB Command that aborts a commit in case the revision number if lower than the one already written in the OVN database. This prevents things like concurrent updates to the same resource. I don't believe we want to disable that.

My 0.2 cents.

one problem which I see here is that in check_servers_hostnames() in case of exception raised it will log console log of instance. If this will happened few times, log will be really noisy and possibly hard to debug.

A couple of comments here:
1. The octavia method allows for routing on the mgmt net, so in theory you can have multiple subnets for your management networks as long as there is a routable path from the controllers to the agents.

nova/test.py.message: Reminder to myself: Need some basic unit tests for these.

This sentence now looks confusing to me. What I meant to say is that here we want to make anonymous admin contexts targeted to the cell database of the compute service during startup tasks, so that records get created in the cell database.

This will only take effect if we poke periodic tasks from the test themselves, not if they are run because their timer happens to come due. Since the timer in Service generates a context each time it runs, those will run with a cell0-targeted context I think.

Also definitely worth a comment here so people know that this wrapper is only for manually-triggered periodic runs.

I thought this should work because I'm temporarily monkey-patching nova.context.get_admin_context here to return the associated cell connection (see L214) before running the real Service.periodic_tasks method. Am I missing something there?

Unless I'm missing something, this is just the thing that is returned to whoever called self.start_service(), which means it's not actually overriding the periodic_tasks() behavior of the Service object. That means if I do this:

  compute = self.start_service('compute')
  compute.periodic_tasks()

then your wrapped version will run. If I do this:

  compute = self.start_service('compute')
  time.sleep(120)

the periodic will run with only Service.periodic_tasks(), no wrapper, since that is what gets passed to the timer.

Thanks for showing that example, I think I understand your point now. The periodic tasks are kicked off in Service's own start method which calls self.periodic_tasks periodically in a thread. I had been thinking erroneously that the oslo timer kept the context and reused it but I see now that it doesn't. So since Service calls self.periodic_tasks, it won't get the wrapped version. :(

I see now what you were saying on IRC about passing a context once and having it be reused each time the timer fires. I wonder if it would be okay to just store it as member data on Service and just reuse it similarly as it is now?

Only used here, which means the wrapper is only returned to the caller of start_service(). If the caller didn't store the result then your wrapper instance goes away immediately because it's no longer needed. Thus it can't have an effect on the timer-based periodics that may run during a long test and/or due to periodic staggered timing luck.

In case anyone is wondering why this has to be done both here and in ServiceWrapper.start, it's because useFixture will call ServiceFixture.setUp which calls Service.create and Service.start and we need Service.start to target the correct cell database because it creates records.

When writing tests, developers can and do call start() separately when stopping/starting services, so cell targeting for that has to be handled in the wrapper separately.

And ServiceWrapper.create doesn't target a cell because no database writes occur in Service.create.

/COMMIT_MSG.message: cell2

I assume you're referring mostly to the handing of a targeted context to Service, and thus compute manager in [2]. The problem with relying on that is that if *any* code in any path that ends up being called by compute manager just does context.get_admin_context(), they'll end up pointing at the wrong database. There may not by any such path currently (although there may be and we're just getting lucky in the execution of this patch), but it would be trivial to add one in the future and have things start failing in a confusing way.

Wasn't only mostly talking about the targeted context to Service, I also think the use of CheatingSerializer is the better way to take care of untargeted get_admin_context(), for example, in the compute manager.

CheatingSerializer accomplishes the same thing that last context manager set out to do, which is essentially carry the db_connection target from nova-api to nova-compute. That's the main reason why I created last context manager when I first wrote CellDatabases. But once CheatingSerializer came on the scene, it mostly removed the usefulness of last context manager. And then once the targeted-context-to-Service change landed, it removed all usefulness that I was aware of.

The only way (I'm aware of) that a get_admin_context() could end up targeting the wrong database, is if someone runs the periodic_tasks manually in a func test without using target_cell around the periodic_tasks call. Periodic tasks do not run automatically because of our ConfFixture setting periodic_enable=False:

https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/d358df32f7a2a1125962e27f2425359c768f79c1/nova/tests/unit/conf_fixture.py#L44
No, you're correct. I was missing this point before.

> Wasn't only mostly talking about the targeted context to Service, I
 > also think the use of CheatingSerializer is the better way to take
 > care of untargeted get_admin_context(), for example, in the compute
 > manager.
 > 
 > CheatingSerializer accomplishes the same thing that last context
 > manager set out to do, which is essentially carry the db_connection
 > target from nova-api to nova-compute.

It does for requests, but if I make a call to compute, CheatingSerializer will hand compute a targeted context. But then if compute (or some code compute uses) calls get_admin_context() (instead of context.elevated()) it will get a context pointing at the default instead of the targeted one, unless I'm misremembering something.

This is the primary complaint, right? That we can add new code to the api that does not target a cell and it's hard to notice that right? If the default cell for api stuff is cell0, then I would think things would only go unnoticed if they don't do anything with computes (or are overly mocked). Maybe we have tests being added that choose cell1 (i.e. not cell0) as the default? If the compute manager is using the service context targeted at cell1, then I would think we should be setting the default cell in the figure to cell0 (like it should be in real life) and then we'd catch the cases where api targets the default cell by default.

That is the primary concern, yes. As we discussed on IRC today, my case was a special one where code in nova/cmd/manage.py targeted a cell, then called a db api method that was not passing a RequestContext in a direct get_engine() call. So each target_cell saved last context manager and the RequestContext-less get_engine() call erroneously got a targeted context via last context manager.

So the default cell never came into play in this case. But in general, I agree that cell0 would be a better default than our current default: cell1, for the reasons you describe.

nova/tests/fixtures.py.message: I know this is the targeted thing to remove, but it's what helped me track down all the places where we were hitting the database from the compute node but not with a request context. If we remove this, we lose that sanity checking. I'm afraid to do that because at real runtime, everything in the compute node is supposed to be untargeted and hitting the compute's default database. In the tests we can't have that be different from the api's default, so we're attempting to always target a context (but only in the tests) to get around that. If we're going to do something like this, I think we need to find a way to catch these leaks if they get added in the future.

I don't think it will, per my other reply. The straight path from api->compute->return is easy. API targets a cell, CheatingSerializer keeps it targeted for the compute, compute uses it, done. It's the case where compute calls something, which calls something, which calls something else, which calls some innocent utility method that ... oopsie, calls get_admin_context() and then you don't have a targeted context.

But, there are definitely dragons in both paths, which I think we agree on :)
IIUC, your case would be covered by CheatingSerializer. See my other comments.
Thanks for clarifying the example you had in mind. I, for whatever reason, was missing it before.

This is the thing that protects us against hitting the wrong database by some deeply-nested piece of code that grabs its own context. In the new code, you'll return the default context manager, which is going to be for cell0 (or something other than what we want). Either that means we'll write something into the wrong database, then read from it and not realize it's wrong, or we'll crash looking for something we swear should be in there but isn't.

I think the scenario you describe would be covered by the behavior of CheatingSerializer (carries RequestContext.db_connection from nova-api to all the other services in the call/cast chain), unless you're talking about func tests containing manual periodic_tasks run calls that are untargeted.
What is the point of even having this wrapper anymore? You're just proxying straight through to the real one now, so no need to mock it anymore right?

/COMMIT_MSG.message:
First line is for commit title and should be up to 50 chars. Second line must be empty. Commit message (description) starts at at third line.

"The first line should be limited to 50 characters and should not end with a period. Subsequent lines should be wrapped at 72 characters."

https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/GitCommitMessages#Summary_of_Git_commit_message_structure

I think this is such a huge change (i don't mean just lines of code, but the whole concepts around how we approach deployment plan) that it would warrant a spec where we describe/discuss the solution from high-level conceptual view. We've already tried to do this twice for updates/upgrades, and we failed twice, so i think our 3rd attempt should be properly thought through on high/conceptual level before we start merging code.

For example -- if we always persist the env files, what should user do when they want to remove some of them etc. I know the commit message says there will be life cycle solved in another patch but so far it's not easy to imagine that.

I mean it's not easy to imagine right now how the final solution would look.

I don't see having specs as a strict requirement in general, but in this case it might be easier to discuss on high level first, to make sure that we go in a direction that reviewers (thinking also DF squad) will agree with and we don't have to rework the proposed code.

Thank you Jiri for your review and yes, I agree, this is a big change.
I will propose a spec for that and I will try to describe with much details as possible what is the current situation and what I have in mind (and why it would be better).

In general, we failed twice as you said probably because we didn't really want to change the whole behavior of the plan management for the deployment.

When I looked at the code and all the calls from the api, I saw that we were doing a lot of "workaround" and "useless" calls to swift or heat to construct the plan.

* So this was my first goal: limited the calls and simplified the code for the plan. (There is still a lot to refactor to get something simple as much as possible).

* My second goal was to keep the environment files, or at least the arguments passed via the cli, just for information and why for being re-used for the update/upgrade.

* A third goal was for the life cycle management: store into swift all the information of the current deployment (env files, parameters & so), and even, give the opportunity to update (upload) a specific files, playbooks or whatever.

This first patch clarified a bit the plan management (1st goal), add the env files and params (2nd goal), but there is still some work to do. Probably to refactor this new code itself. I first wanted to see what I could potentially break with it and see if this solution and refactoring was something "doable" or "not at all".
So I got successful deployments (classic, config download) and upgrades with it.

So I'm going to propose a spec with the review attached... And thank you again for your (precious) feedback..

Thanks, the above makes sense and i agree the persistence is a valuable feature to have and also it's valuable to simplify the plan management approach (with user_env and plan_env which kinda collide). Thanks a lot for looking into this :)

Yes, but the binary thing is an actual field in the resource in the API, so binary is nova-compute, or nova-conductor, or nova-scheduler, etc. Since these docs are talking about "compute services" it can be confusing because if you take compute == nova, then nova-conductor and nova-scheduler are compute services, but what I really mean here is only services with binary == 'nova-compute' are allowed for this API call.

Only services with ``"binary": "nova-compute"`` are allowed.

https://developer.openstack.org/api-ref/compute/?expanded=#servers-actions-servers-os-instance-actions

I'm just not sure if the description in the API reference is correct, i.e. is the action user_id the user that owns the server or the user that initiated the action (I think it's the latter):

https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/5c6c1f8fce7cd976dedc0a1ad28836ed87af2780/nova/objects/instance_action.py#L56

Then we definitely have an alternative to what's proposed here - just use the instance actions API which is already our server audit log API more or less.

I agree with you, but by request_id to find user_id is not accurate.
Add the user_id field to obtain the user_id of the migration operation is accurate. 
In practical applications, it is necessary to achieve accuracy.
The problem of frequent migration operations, I think it should enhance the stability
of the product, and can not limit the implementation of new features because of this problem.
At the same time, the problem of Huawei's public cloud can not explain that other public clouds
will have similar problems.

I'm not totally against adding user_id and project_id to migration records to track who initiated the migrations.

I think they do happen frequently in public clouds during upgrades to avoid downtime (Huawei public cloud and Vexxhost do a lot of live migrations for upgrades when you have a lot of compute nodes and can't have downtime unlike in a private cloud with weekend maintenance windows).

I don't like the overlap of the user_id/project_id duplication with instance action records, but as noted above there aren't great alternatives to try and avoid that duplication.

Also, migration records are more or less top-level kind of resources in the compute API, like servers, so I don't think it's totally unreasonable to track who initiated the migration on that record itself.

I'm still -1 on the spec since it needs quite a bit of cleaning up and explaining that it could be possible - although quite complicated and potentially error prone - to figure out who initiated a migration using instance action records as I've described, but the proposal is much simpler than that alternative.

> Hi! I have a question, how do I match the user_id of instance
 > action with the instance in migration DB?
 > There are two matching methods:
 > 1. Match according to the request ID.
 > 2. Add the user_id field in the migration record database.
 > However, the request ID and user_id are not recorded in the
 > migration DB.
 > Therefore, it is necessary to add user_id field to the migration
 > DB.

To filter all live migrations for a given server, you could do that like:

GET /os-migrations?instance_uuid=<server_id>&migration_type=live-migration

For instance actions on a server, you can get those:

GET /servers/{server_id}/os-instance-actions

And then filter the action(s) client-side by the action value. For live migration that would be "live-migration".

The problem is if you have multiple live migrations for the same server, there is not a clear correlation for which action is tied to which migration record. One could possibly sort that out client-side by filtering the actions and migrations based on the created_at or updated_at fields somehow, i.e. if the server is live migrated on Monday, Tuesday and Thursday, then you could correlate that using the created_at values for the associated actions and migrations records in the API - but I admit that's not very graceful and could be error prone if you have multiple live migrations on the same server in the same day.

In general it feels wrong to me to include the user_id (and arguably we'd also want to include the project_id also) in the migrations records for the context that initiated the request since that overlaps so much with instance actions, but I can see how trying to correlate who initiated a migration could be confusing as described above. I seem to remember Zhenyu (Kevin) Zheng from Huawei bringing up the idea of storing the request ID in the migrations record so that instance actions could be correlated with the migrations using the request ID which is part of the primary key for actions, but that was awhile ago and I think for what he needed at the time we resolved by storing the host on the action in 2.62:

https://docs.openstack.org/nova/latest/reference/api-microversion-history.html#id56

We can ask Kevin if he's work on a similar issue or can remember why he wanted to include the request ID in the migrations records.

Hi matt, you said this implementation, through the combination of `GET /os-migrations` and `GET /servers/{server_id}/os-instance-actions` to obtain the migration record of the server, in the case of a single situation to meet customer needs.

For example, if there is only userA in the test project, then no matter how many times he migrates to the server, the records queried here are credible. However, if there are multiple users (userA, userB, userC ...) under the test project, this method is undoubtedly undesirable, although the migration record can be obtained through the request ID, it is not known who migrated the server.

We have deployed our own OpenStack products in the financial, telecommunications and other industries. We get this information in communication with users.

As an administrator, I need to know if the server under the project has been migrated. who is it? When and where to go? (maybe it's mainly), this helps help customers manage.

In summary, I think it is necessary to add 'user_id' and /or 'project_id' to the migration records. I think *migration* is not performed frequently in the customer environment, except in the event of a failure.

specs/stein/approved/support-delete-on-t.message: This is really confusing. Why have a list when we're attaching a single resource? In other words, I would avoid trying to re-use the block_device_mapping_v2 schema from the server create API and just have bdm-specific fields in the volume attach API, which would just be a new "delete_on_termination" parameter in this case.
Yes, this method only attach a single volume to an instance, there is necessary to use block_device_mapping_v2 dict, I will remove it the BDM_V2.

I don't think this is awkward, we added delete_on_termination to volumes while boot a bfv instance from image, that is because the volume will be created by Nova telling Cinder, and that makes sense. What you are proposing here is a new proxy API or orchestrate API to Cinder, this will make the whole process complicated. I assume you have a orchestrating service on top of your OpenStack services, why not do this there? it could much simple

Thanks Kevin.
Perhaps this sentence is not appropriate, and it has caused misunderstandings.
Yeah, we can add 'delete_on_termination' while boot a volume-backend instance from a image, but this is only for root device, if you attach a volume to an exist instance, that won't make any changes to 'delete_on_termination'.

This spec proposing to volume attach API, when we attach a volume to an instance can config for 'delete_on_termination'.

specs/train/approved/support-delete-on-t.message: This is describing https://review.opendev.org/#/c/580336/ isn't it?

This is the more complicated spec - why not decouple these? Adding a delete_on_termination flag to the attach volume API is pretty trivial, but updating the value on an already attached volume is less so because the existing PUT API for volume attachments is only used for swap volume operations today, which is why that other spec is messier. If you were to decouple these specs so this one just focuses on the ability to specify the flag when attaching the volume (but leave the other spec to worry about *changing* the value on already-attached volumes), then this spec has a better chance of being approved for Train.
Emm...Yes, this is confusing, which is a duplicate of the description at https://review.opendev.org/#/c/580336/.
The alternative is the user cleans up the data volumes manually after deleting the server as they would have to do today.
This sample doesn't seem to match the proposed change description above where you're talking about a list of block_device_mapping_v2 dicts. Which is it?

This isn't described in the proposed change section either as far as I can tell. Detaching a volume from a server today doesn't take a request body:

https://developer.openstack.org/api-ref/compute/?expanded=detach-a-volume-from-an-instance-detail#detach-a-volume-from-an-instance

Are you proposing that we now should take a request body on detach to tell nova whether or not to delete the volume on detach? If so, I don't think that makes a lot of sense - we don't delete delete_on_termination=true volumes today when they are attached, e.g. say I create a server with data volume 1 and specified delete_on_termination=true during server create, but then detach the volume because I want to re-use it for some other server, maybe a recovery or backup server, nova won't delete the volume on detach.

This must be wrong - did you mean something else? Like, "User will be able to attach data volumes and specify during the attach request whether or not those volumes should also be deleted when the server is deleted."
Your example is what I want to express.

This isn't in the request payload above...and I'm not sure what it means for the "nova volume-attach" CLI anyway.

Do you mean that these APIs would now return the delete_on_termination parameter in the response body (they probably should as part of this change):

GET /servers/{server_id}/os-volume_attachments

GET /servers/{server_id}/os-volume_attachments/{volume_id}

That way the user could see which attached volumes are marked for deletion in the CLI if it's in the GET responses.

Depending on how this is implemented, there could be an upgrade impact because when attaching a volume to a non-shelved offloaded server, the API makes an RPC call to compute which creates the BDM record:

https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/89712fe834942a85be3441ed175a79ff696bfe01/nova/compute/manager.py#L5789

If the instance is on a Stein level compute during a rolling upgrade, we'd fail to set the delete_on_termination flag. If you implemented this feature such that the compute doesn't set the delete_on_termination field on the created BDM, but instead the API does, somewhere like here:

https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/89712fe834942a85be3441ed175a79ff696bfe01/nova/compute/api.py#L3920

Then older computes aren't an issue.
We also need to update python-openstackclient.
I don't think we probably need tempest tests for this - functional tests should be sufficient with the CinderFixture to know that the attached volume was deleted or not when the server was deleted.
